# JOIN US

Founded in 1931, PhilaLandmarks is Philadelphia’s oldest society centered on preserving historic houses. Members are partners in our mission to engage a broad range of diverse audiences about American history through compelling exhibitions, stimulating programming, and educational initiatives. Our goal is to bring history and culture to life and connect people together in conversation and community.

Like the _Hare_ -_Powel direct descendants_ at left — _Thomas Ives Hare Powel Jr., Jonathan Knight Bitting & Ret. Rear Admiral Townsend Alexander_ — we hope you consider both becoming a member and supporting us with donations. Because keeping our history alive and relevant to new generations is critical to our democracy.

## Core Membership Benefit

Included at Every Level:

  1. Free unlimited admission to all four historic houses.

  2. Advance notification of our public programs.

  3. Invitations to our public events and tours, sometimes including free or discounted tickets.

  4. Invitation to attend the Annual Meeting. 

  5. PhilaLandmarks Newsletter emailed every month.

  6. Special offers from our PhilaLandmarks’ partners: Hidden City Philadelphia, Historic Germantown, Cliveden, Christ Church Burial Ground, Early Music Series Partners, Historical Society of Pennsylvania, Tiny Dynamite, Ghost Tours of Philadelphia.

  7. Recognition in our Annual Report.

# GRUMBLETHORPE 

# Grumblethorpe 

_Germantown 1744_

[ Click here for Grumblethorpe News and Events ](/grumblethorpe-home)

German immigrant John Wister (Johannes Wüster, 1705-1789) built this house in 1744 as a family country home outside of Philadelphia. Constructed of local Wissahickon schist and oak timbers hewn from Wister’s woods, the house is a prime example of Germantown architecture of the period. 

Notable features include the stone coursing of the facade, front and rear balconies and the double front entrances. The property included a farm, gardens, and orchards with fruit trees to supplement John’s wine importing business. 

Known through-out the 18th century as _John Wister’s_ _Big House_ , Grumblethorpe was just one of John’s many properties in Philadelphia and Lancaster. Intended as a summer retreat, the house provided a refuge for the family from the humid Philadelphia summers, and in 1793, the family stayed in Germantown to avoid the yellow fever epidemic. 

This house was also taken over by the British and used as one of its headquarters during the Battle of Germantown in October 1777, as John Wister was staying in his Market Street home in Philadelphia and John’s son Daniel and his family had fled to a relative’s house in what is now Lower Gwynedd.
